book.title: Statistics with Python: 100 Solved Exercises for Data Analysis
book.author: Gianluca Malato (Parsed by LEO AI)
book.description: A practical guide to statistics using Python, covering probability, descriptive statistics, and hypothesis testing.

sections.summary: Probability is the measure of the likelihood that an event will occur, ranging from 0 to 1.
content: A random experiment is a process with an uncertain outcome.
The set of all possible outcomes is called the Sample Space (S).
An Event (E) is a subset of the Sample Space.
The probability P(A) of an event A is the number of favorable outcomes divided by the total number of possible outcomes.

sections.summary: The arithmetic mean provides the central point of a data distribution.
content: The mean is calculated as the sum of elements divided by the count.
In Python, use `numpy.mean(data)` for efficient calculation.
Pandas allows calculating means across columns using `df.mean()`.
Note: The mean is highly sensitive to outliers.

sections.summary: Standard deviation measures the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values.
content: A low standard deviation indicates that the data points tend to be close to the mean.
Variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
Standard deviation is the square root of the variance.
Python implementation: `df['column'].std()` using pandas.

sections.section_title: Identification of Outliers with IQR Method
sections.summary: The Interquartile Range (IQR) method is a robust way to detect anomalies in data.
content: IQR is calculated as Q3 (75th percentile) minus Q1 (25th percentile).
Outliers are typically defined as values below Q1 - 1.5*IQR or above Q3 + 1.5*IQR.
This method is more robust than the Z-score for non-normal distributions.
Visualizing outliers is best done with a boxplot using `seaborn.boxplot()`.

sections.summary: Linear regression models the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
content: The model assumes a linear relationship: y = mx + c.
Correlation coefficient (r) measures the strength of this linear relationship.
In Python, `sklearn.linear_model.LinearRegression` is the standard tool for modeling.
Evaluation metrics include R-squared and Mean Squared Error (MSE).

sections.summary: The normal distribution is the most important probability distribution in statistics due to the Central Limit Theorem.
content: Characterized by its mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ).
Approximately 68% of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
A Standard Normal Distribution has a mean of 0 and a variance of 1.
Use `scipy.stats.norm.pdf()` to calculate the probability density function in Python.
